desc: ab+1, bc+1, ca+1 are factorials find (a,b,c)
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Let $ab+1=p!,\ bc+1=q!,\ ca+1=r!$.

  If $\min\{p,q,r\}\ge 3$, then $ab\equiv -1$,
  $bc\equiv -1$, $ca\equiv -1$ modulo $3$.
  Multiplying these three, we get
  \[
    (abc)^2\equiv -1 \pmod 3,
  \]
  which is not possible as perfect squares are either
  $0$ or $1$ modulo $3$.

  So $\min\{p,q,r\}\le 2$.
  WLOG assume $p$ is the minimum.
  As $p=ab+1\ge 2$, we have $p\ge 2$.
  This forces $p=2$, which further forces $a=b=1$.
  So $c=q!-1=r!-1$.

  It is easy to see that all triplets of the form
  $(1,1,n!-1)$, $n\ge 2$, and their permutations work.
\end{soln}
